entry.title: Welcome to Artisanal Intelligence
entry.content:
title: â€œWelcome to Artisanal Intelligenceâ€ date: 2025-04-10 author: crankbird layout: post â€”

Welcome to Artisanal Intelligence

A place where technology meets intentionality, and code meets craft.

Modern artificial intelligence often feels like mass production â€” sprawling neural networks, industrial-scale data centers, and opaque algorithms trained on oceans of data. But what if intelligence could be artisanal?

ğŸ§  What Do We Mean by â€œArtisanalâ€?

The term artisanal might evoke images of sourdough bread, handmade furniture, or carefully roasted coffee. But in the context of AI, it suggests something more subtle: a human-centered, intentional approach to building and understanding intelligence.

Why â€œArtisanalâ€ and Not â€œArtificialâ€?

  • Artisanal intelligence is curated. Instead of training models on everything, we might train them on something â€” something meaningful, contextual, or intentionally chosen.
  • It values transparency. Like watching a baker knead dough, we believe in models that you can understand and even tinker with.
  • Itâ€™s designed for collaboration. Not to replace people, but to augment them. To partner with them. To amplify judgment, not override it.

ğŸ› ï¸ Tools, Not Gods

â€œThe best tools donâ€™t make decisions for you. They help you think better.â€

Many modern AI systems are black boxes. Artisanal Intelligence seeks the opposite: white boxes that support clarity. We believe that design matters. That a well-structured prompt is as important as the model that reads it. That interface is part of intelligence.

Hereâ€™s what that might look like in practice:

1
2
3
4

- handcrafted_models: true
- modular_components: true
- human_feedback: required
- corporate_buzzwords: deprecated
entry.summary: Launching a blog grounded in transparency, clarity, and attribution.

entry.title: Sample Post with Rich Metadata
entry.content:
Sample Post with Rich Metadata

Welcome to another sample post on Artisanal Intelligence â€” this one is designed to stretch your blog layout and stress-test rich metadata rendering. If youâ€™re seeing this, your Jekyll setup is alive and well. Letâ€™s dive in.

ğŸ§­ What This Post Covers

This is a fully featured sample post to help you test:

  • Rendering of headers and lists
  • Syntax highlighting in code blocks
  • Embedded tables and blockquotes
  • Images and inline metadata usage
  • Horizontal rules and callouts
  • Frontmatter parsing in layout

ğŸ§  Why This Matters

â€œA well-structured test post tells you more about your theme than ten broken layouts.â€

Most blog engines work fine for minimal content. But as your blog matures, youâ€™ll want:

  • Good typography for longer reads
  • Semantic support for content like tutorials
  • A flexible layout that works for both casual and technical audiences

This post helps you simulate that real-world complexity â€” without resorting to lorem ipsum.

ğŸ”§ Sample Code Snippet

Hereâ€™s a simple Python function using syntax highlighting:

1
2
3
4
5

def greet(name):
    print(f"Hello, {name}. Welcome to Artisanal Intelligence.")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    greet("crankbird")
entry.summary: This is a sample post to test the enhanced layout with rich metadata and content.
